title: Visual Arts Management
description: This course leads students to study various modes and philosophies of visual arts management undertaken in different venues. Aesthetics and art criticisms are critical in directing art interpretation and presentation. Contemporary management of visual arts responds predominantly to the worldwide discussions on modernism as well as various post-modernist writings. In addition, it has to operate in accordance with the prescribed state policy. For this bilateral concern of art management, the course comprises two sections. The first section leads students to study the writings on aesthetics by critics from Plato to Foucault, whose arguments are still valid in inspiring many art exhibitions. The second section discusses the practical concerns and techniques in maximizing the social and economic impacts of art exhibitions and relevant events. Both sections discuss case studies taken from different parts of the world.
outcome: Upon completion of the course, students will be able to describe different categories of visual arts in professional language; to define and explain the key terms in visual art literature; to appreciate and analyze art exhibitions with reference to intellectual debates on aesthetics; to describe and explain the art policies implemented in East Asia and the West; and to develop independent thinking on the operation and promotion of art organizations.
syllabus: Section I: Aesthetics and art criticisms   1. Introduction: Shifting perspectives on visual art management in the 20th century  Visual art management was a new discipline born in late 19th century when museums appeared in Europe. This session reviews the early practices in museum curatorship and its transformations under the impact of modernism. It explains how the focus in managing visual art shifted from scholarly field to public arena in the 21st century.   2. ‘Is it good art?’: From Plato, Hume to Danto on aesthetics  ‘What is beauty?’ has been the most discussed topic in Western art history since the times of Plato. This session discusses the canonical writings by Plato and his followers and critics during the times of Renaissance. The discussion links to their contributions to the post-modern theories that still weigh importantly today.   3. Visuality and Perception The intention of artists and the perception of arts of the beholders are core issues in Western aesthetics. This section discusses the most well-read writings by Ernest Gombrich and John Berger, who respond to the question as to whether arts comprise social values.   4. ‘Does Fine Arts still stand today?’: From fine arts to commercial arts  Visual arts comprise a wide range of categories today that include both traditional oil paintings and sculpture, as well as contemporary art forms that includes installation, and industrial designs. This section discusses the shifting definitions of arts and the incorporation of commercial arts in exhibitions.   5. Cross-cultural aesthetics  Are Western art theories applicable to the Asian contexts? Correlation exists between civilization and visual culture. This session discusses the Chinese visual art system and explains its difference from that in the West.   Section II: Concerns and Practices   6. Writing and arts  This lecture analyzes different texts about visual arts taken from museum exhibition catalogues, auction house catalogues, newspaper reviews, as well as commercial gallery publications. This leads students to reflect on the different presentations of arts for education and commercial purposes.   7. Arts and state  This lectures discusses the various policies implemented in the US, UK, and China that enables or hinders the developments of art organizations and individual artists.   8. Business and Arts  Artists and art organizations s management relies heavily on the patronage of business firm. This session discuss the mutual relationship between arts and business, as well as their shifting roles in recent decades.   9. Audience and arts  This lecture extends the discussion of the last, and focuses on the concerns and strategies of art and cultural promoters in non-profit, educational sectors. This introduces the issue of branding implemented in many world renowned institutes and evaluates their success.   10. Managers and arts  This lecture discusses human resources management in the art industry. Examples of excellent directorship taken from the UK and US will be studied to shed light on the significance of professional leadership in the discipline.   11. The Biennial fever  Bienne is world recognized art event to showcase and acknowledge the achievements of young artists. This lecture discusses the organization and social impacts of the bienne festivals held in Europe and Asia.   12. Artist villages  Artist village is developing everywhere in the world. This lectures discusses the examples found in China and Taiwan and leads students to think whether Hong Kong will need an artist cluster for future cultural developments.   13. Art events and festivals  Annual art events and festivals serve as major strategies to generate social and economic support for art today. This lecture discusses the organization and planning of those events and evaluate the examples taken from Europe, US and Asia.

title: Performing Arts Management
description: This course discusses the missions, administrations, and strategies of performing art organizations. Since the 1950s, performing art managers have realized the significance of efficient management in achieving popularity and sale. This course will go through the general topics as to how the performing art organizations are administered in national and legal terms; how they solicit funding; how they are operated in terms of ticketing and touring; and how they are strategically promoted for both branding and social benefits.
outcome: Upon completion of the course, students will be able to describe the practical concerns of the performing art organizations in terms of their daily operation; to identify various sources of funding in support of performing arts; to evaluate the administration structure and strategies undertaken in different countries; and describe and explain the different policies implemented in East Asia and the West.
syllabus: 1. Introduction: Profit-making vs Non-profiting making performing houses  This lecture introduces the basic, binal division between two different types of performing houses. This leads students to reflect on the confliciting aims between the two types, and realize the significance of the overlapping features of the two.   2. Setting up the ‘mission’ Clear directorship is recognizedly important among performing arts management. This lecture analyzes the various mission statements and approach of the performing houses in Europe, US and China. This discusses how a mission statement is being written up and executed.   3. Legal rights and obligations of non-profit making organizations.  This lecture discusses the legal terms of the non-profiting making performing organizations, and provides an in-depth study towards their social obligations in exchange for tax exemption.   4. Commercial productions.  This lecture discusses the concerns and strategies of Broadway productions. Examples of programming and touring techniques of the theatres in the US, France and China will be discussed.   5. Budget planning  Financial management in the performing industry aims to maintain balance between expenses and revenue. This lecture discusses the management of book keeping, payroll taxes, facilities maintenance, and auditing.   6. Fund-raising possibilities for non-profit performing houses  There are many fund-raising opportunities for non-profit organizations. Managers usually have to work closely with the Board of Directors. Tactics in securing interests and long-term partnerships with external and potential donors will be discussed.  7. Sale and ticketing  Following up with the last session, this lecture discusses the marketing management of commercial productions. The role of ticket office and various advertising skills will be compared and discussed.   8. Performing arts and education  This lecture discusses the American tactics in engaging junior and high school students in performing arts. It discusses the experience of the New York City Centre and the Kennedy Centre. This session invites students to reflect on the social impacts of the performing industry through arts education.   9. Human resources  Theatres and Orchestras work closely with large numbers of members from various sorts of backgrounds. Management in labor relations has always been a key to achieve success in the performing industry. This section introduces various labour unions and legal regulations towards employment contracts.   10. Touring production  Touring is a common tactic employed to increase revenue by taking the performing crew overseas. However, touring means many risks that may increase expenses. This lecture discusses the benefits and shortcomings in taking a production on a tour.   11. Facility management  Facilities maintenance assumes a large share of expense on the financial sheet of presenters. This session discusses the contracting tactics in keeping the costs low. In addition, it also discusses event programming that draws attention to the management of facilities.   12. Internship and youth programmes  This lecture discusses the outreach options for performing houses. It will focus on the networking and partnership formed on the basis of short-term internship; and on the audience-engaging programme that develops the audience base of different age range.   13. Presentation  Student presentation of group project.

title: New Media Arts Management
description: This course introduces a new genre in the art discipline that employs electronic and digital devices as the main medium of communication. The course contains three sessions. The first session explains the birth of this set of contemporary art practices in relation to the Dadaist movement of the early twentieth century that opened up new concepts for visual arts. This will be followed by a session that discusses the range of media now commonly adopted in the discipline, including video, photography, computer graphics, webpage, and the Internet. Different set of techniques are involved in these productions, and they often generate quite different social impacts that affect both the producers and the users. Students are instructed to understand both the technological and social aspects of these areas. The last session comprises a series of workshops that lead students to appreciate and comment on the most featured productions. Emphasis is placed on the angle to promote this new art type as a rising cultural sector in the society.
outcome: Upon completion of the course, students will be able to describe and define the technical terms employed in the new media productions; to acquire the basic techniques involved in shooting, controlling sound effect, and designing for interactive visual experience; to identify the software and skills essential for creating different virtual experience; to recognize the economic aspects of using multi-media in cultural sectors; to analyze the social coverage and impacts of using the Internet for distribution; and to develop independent thinking about the cyber-culture and artificial identity.
syllabus: 1.Art and Technology The history of new media art began in the early 20th century. The well-read article by Walter Benjamin defines a new age in art distribution. This lecture discusses the adoption of technological devices in modern art production, as well as the impact factors of using technology that both contribute to and alter the original aims of traditional arts.   2.How ‘new’ is the New Media?  How does ‘New Media’ differ from the old one? Why was it born? This lecture discusses the work by Dali and Duchamp, as well as their critiques. It looks at how the artists found interests in the new devices and how they employed so in expressing thoughts and feelings during the so-called Dadaist and Pop Movement.   3.Virtual Effects and Visual Culture New technologies gave visual culture a new life in the 20th century that opened up many different opportunities of making interaction through the use of prints, drawings, photographs, and videos. This lecture discusses the concepts of simulation and immersion in visual arts. It also introduces the concept of virtual reality, which has been widely applied in both two and three-dimensional work.   4.Films and Animations  This lecture continues the last one in discussing the idea of realism and representation in media production. This one focuses on the images reproduced in films and video games. It discusses the theories employed in photography and filming with digital devices that lead students to think how the new technologies alter the traditional views about representation.   5.Economy and the Web Media  The New Media is often regarded as being reasonably economical in operation, compared with other traditional means of presentation. This lecture discusses the economic aspects of using different web engines and forums, as well as the commercial limits in employing those devices.   6. Wikis and Web 2.0  Web 2.0 is a concept introduced at the beginning of this century to describe the combination of software (HTML), hardware, and Internet in forming a major sector of social interaction. The Wikipedia introduced in 2004 gave every user a new participant identity in the virtual world. This lecture discusses how the boom of Internet information alter social practices and ideas.   7.Games, Animation And the Cyber-world In countries, such as Japan and Korea, games and animation form a major sector in the creative industries. This lecture introduces the Dreamweaver and Power Game Factory. It discusses the social impacts of those new entertaining devices in re-defining the issues of gender, ethnics, and even national identities.   8. Workshop I: Installation and Contemporary Arts  In this workshop session, the instructor will lead students to look at the classic examples of installation in contemporary art display. The work by Damien Hurst, Cai Guoqiang, Xu Bing, and other contemporary artists will be discussed.   9. Workshop II: Editing Techniques in Photography This workshop leads students to practice photography and understand the central theories in shooting in relation to previous lecture on visual culture.   10. Workshop III: Editing Techniques in Filming  This workshop teaches students the skills in editing and handling effects with Final Cut Pro and Snapz.  11. title: Public and Community Art
description: Public art is considered as an important cultural asset of metropolitan cities, closely related to city images and development. Community art serves as a tool for community development, based on the understanding that expression, mastery and communication through the arts powerfully encode cultural values, thus bringing deeper meanings of experience, participation and involvement, sense of belonging to the general public and the community. This course aims to advance students’ understanding of public and community arts by embedding them in the theoretical discussions and critiques of cities and public spaces and practical experiences. It also imparts the knowledge and skills about managing public arts and actualizing community art programs, and discusses the way to support their development responding to the needs.
outcome: In terms of knowledge acquisition, students are expected to understand how public and community arts emerged in the context of urban regeneration and community activist movements. Students are encouraged to critically analyze the meanings and social values of public art spaces. In terms of managerial concepts and skills, students will learn how public and community arts are supported by government policies, material resources, infrastructure and training. Students are expected to understand public art commission and reception, to master basic principles of utilizing public art as an urban design strategy, and to apply varying approaches to facilitating community art development, for example, advancing community art education, utilizing the cultural planning approach to assess community based cultural resources and the place-event approach to creating a sense of community attachment.
syllabus: Part I. Understanding Public and Community Art 1. General Introduction This section begins with displaying a range of public and community art cases and presents an introduction to the course. Three issues are covered in this introductory lecture. First, this section provides the conceptual discussions of public space, public art, and their art forms to enable students to understand what public art space and public art is. Second, this section explores the role of artists in public art space and community development. Third, a historical picture of public art is unfolded, which traces its origin, displays its developing process, and takes a glimpse into its enshrined social values.   2. Understanding Public Art Spaces  How should we understand public art spaces and the public nature of public art? This section embeds these issues into the understanding of a city; it then conveys the ideas that public spaces are socially produced and that city forms are imbued with ideologies. Public art stems from an urban setting and then grows through the urban regeneration movement, which comprises several issues, such as urban image, urban form and urban planning as well as their connections with public art space as a form of representational space. Furthermore, this section explores the public nature of public art by examining the process, by which artists derive value from individual creativity in the studios and immense it into the public space.  Tutorial: Discuss the alternative history of public art (Lacy, 1995, 25–28).  3. Public Art: The Monument The monument is an important theoretical perspective to conceptualize public art. This section explains what a “monument” is and investigates its role—whether statue, memorial, or public statue—in upholding a value-laden system of Western society. Issues under examination range from the connection between monument and national identity, the power and representation of public arts, the transformative understanding of public art as a monument, and the contradictions of public art.  Tutorial: Discuss the public nature of public art.  4. Critical Issues of Public Art Spaces Who comprise the “audience” of public arts? What does “intention” mean and what is the “effectiveness” of public art? This section further discusses the theories on critical issues related to public art. This section begins with the discussions of the relevant terms and proceeds to various critical thoughts that challenge the value of public art and question its public nature. Students are expected to be able to analyze public art spaces and public art critically. Tutorial: Develop critical thinking about public art spaces and public art.  5. Public Arts and Community Cultural Development: Theoretical Underpinnings of Community Art This section provides a synopsis of the histories and theoretical issues of community art. The origin of community art is traced to the discourse of William Morris’s call for social reintegration of artists and a revival of art in the 19th century. Theoretical issues include the “popular front” and class consciousness, civil rights and identity politics, as well as cultural democracy and exchange. In addition, this section discusses the definitions of community, the role of community art, and the core purposes of community development.  Tutorial: Discuss the question, “What makes art valuable?”   Part II. Public Art Management  6. Commission and Reception of Public Art Based on the public nature of art, this section analyzes the process of art making, which comprises the elements of audience, context, and meaning. The process includes the following: acquiring cultural approval, arriving in public sites and places, providing visiting experiences with the audience, and generating meanings. Cases of Seattle and New York are used for this study. With regard to art reception, it analyzes the issues of taste, the education of the audience, as well as the relationship of art to society and popular visual culture. In addition, this section also distinguishes performance culture from monumental public art. Tutorial: Distinguish public art from community art.  7. Public Art and Urban Design This section presents an urban design approach to commissioning and making public art. It outlines the principles for creating a city image, which consists of five elements, and discusses their connections to public art. Various forms of public art in association with the urban setting and the mechanism of public art utilization as an urban design strategy are also discussed. Students are guided toward understanding the role of public arts in urban design guidelines. Moreover, we also discussed a set of design principles on the relationship between public art and various urban forms and spatial components, aimed at integrating public art into the urban setting as context and reference is discussed. Tutorial: Conduct design software training.  Assignment: Find a sample of public art (i.e., sculpture) using design principles to assess its location, site, and designs as well as to evaluate its strengths and weaknesses. Write a paper based on the research and use the design software to illustrate the arguments.   8. Government Policies for Public and Community Art Development The relation between power and public and community art is a critical issue in public and community art management. This section discusses the governmental structure that funds and commissions public art, the infrastructure that underpins public art, and the governmental policies that support community art. The selection of commissions and projects is discussed, along with the process of seeking public and professional responses. International and the local Hong Kong contexts are examined to explore how government policies affect public and community art. In the local context, the role of the Leisure and Cultural Services Department in promoting public art in Hong Kong is adopted as a case study. Tutorial: Conduct an in-class test.   9. Public Art in Metropolitan Cities This section analyzes the role of public art in metropolitan cities, especially in the spheres of public transport, public open spaces, and public health system. A number of cases are presented, including forms of public art in the New York Subway system, London Underground and Mass Transit Railway, and the Queen Elizabeth Hospital in Hong Kong. The issue of commissioning public arts is revisited in the public art in metropolitan context.  Tutorial: Discuss urban design and public art in Hong Kong.  Part III. Community Art Management 10. Developmental Needs of the Field How can community art development be supported? What do communities need? This section specifies the scope of cultural policies and the policy climate that community artists and community cultural development require. Moreover, this section discusses the material support that community cultural organizations and artists need, including funding supports and internal infrastructure and exchange. Tutorial: Discuss the cultural policies for public art in Hong Kong.  11. From Theory to Practice I: Process to Develop Community Arts From theory to practice, this section offers students a general orientation, which serves as a road map to the community-based art process. Five conceptual territories to advance community-based art as well as requisite techniques to fulfill tasks are introduced in this section, which include the following: 1) contacting people in the community; 2) conducting research on the culture of the community and the people’s perception of their community; 3) taking actions to make art projects; 4) gaining feedbacks from the community; and 5) incorporating these art forms into community art education programs to pass on skills and sustain the impact. The program also includes strategies for planning and organizing community outreach and engagement programs as well as ways to enhance public awareness. Tutorial: Discuss the process of applying theories in the creation of community art in order to practice and initiate the group project with the community.  12. From Theory to Practice II: Key Issues in Community Art Development Based on the holistic picture of the steps to develop community arts, this section focuses on certain key and challenging issues in the process, specifically those on research methods and art making. The section introduces qualitative and quantitative research methods for the project of community art development, and students are expected to learn how to identify survey areas, design survey questionnaires, run group discussions, and map cultural mind-sets and assets. Another key issue is how to make arts and work with artists. An artist will be invited to be the guest speaker to give the lesson. Tutorial: Develop a group project with the community.   13. Review and discussions Students will present their on-going group projects on community art development, and the professor then provides comments and feedbacks on their projects. Key points of this course will also be reviewed in this class.

title: Design Your Exhibition – Curatorial Planning and Practice
description: “Curator” once referred to an expert in keeping collections and making exhibitions, but has been expanded to encompass a hybrid role in innovation and knowledge creation. Today, curators are active agents in social and cultural transformation, taking part in dynamic projects presented by museums, commercial galleries, non-profit art spaces, biennials, art fairs, and many disruptive platforms beyond the field of art that didn’t previously exist. Curators produce knowledge, engage their audience, spark innovation, and constantly challenge the role of “curator” beyond the confines of the status quo across varied institutional settings. This course aims to provide students with hands-on experience in exhibition curation and engages students in a broad spectrum of real-world experiences and professional networking opportunities, aiming to prepare students for future curatorial projects/jobs. It covers topics such as idea conceptualization, proposal writing, pitching, budgeting, contracting, publication, exhibition design, installation and exhibition maintenance. By co-curating an exhibition in a non-profit art space in Hong Kong, students will take part in the various stages of exhibition making. With a focus on exhibition experience, audience engagement, and sociability, this course will train students in the role of being a curator and enable students to develop leadership skills and critically apply knowledge conducive to creative outcomes.
outcome: Upon completing the course, students will be able to: • Explain the key roles of being a curator • Develop skills in the various stages of exhibition making from a broad spectrum of real-world experience and professional networking opportunities • Acquire personal and social competencies to work cooperatively in a team  • Develop critical analysis skills concerning exhibition experiences, audience engagement and sociability • Develop an attitude of innovation and creativity by challenging assumptions in the ever-expanding field of curation

title: Entrepreneurship in the Creative Industries
description: The concept of “creative industry” was proposed by the Labor Party in the U.K. in 1997. It refers to the activities that are embedded in individuals’ creativities, talents and skills, which have the potential for employment opportunities and economic growth through the exploitation of intellectual properties. Creative industry has become a key area in contemporary cultural policies. This course introduces students to the basic knowledge of managing entrepreneurship, which is a key issue in the creative industries. It comprises three parts. The first part provides a general introduction. The second part discusses the nature of entrepreneurship in creative industries and demonstrates the entrepreneurial process, through which, creative ideas are generated, cultural diffusion is stimulated and innovation processes are carried out. It informs students of the key traits of the creative entrepreneurs and the business opportunities and models for entrepreneurship processes in the creative industries. In the third part, it explores the conducive policy conditions to support and encourage entrepreneurship in creative industries.
outcome: By the end of this course, a student will:  i) Have their understanding being deepened about creative industries and entrepreneurship ii) Value and appreciate entrepreneurial spirits in the creative industries  iii) Develop sets of skills for entrepreneurial practices  iv) Understand the policy conditions for entrepreneurship and acquire consultation skills for the government
syllabus: Part 1: General Introduction  Lecture 1: Creative industries and entrepreneurship: A brief introduction The first lecture in this course will brief the concept of “creative industry” and introduce the key issues of creative industries (e.g., its developmental path, the main traits and its importance to economic growth). Entrepreneurship is a concept key to creative industry development: the creation of new business ventures and the conditions that define corporate venturing will be discussed.  Readings:  CCPR, 2003, 13-26; Harley et. al., 2013, 58-61  Lecture 2: Key issues for stakeholders in the creative industries: A global perspective The development of the creative economy is widely concerned by policymakers, regional and local government and the business community. This section will explore how stakeholders face these issues in creative industries. It will also introduce creative industry development and entrepreneurship in Asia.  Readings:  Ghosh and Malloy, 2011, 12-15; Hui, 2007, 9-29  Part 2: The Entrepreneurial Process  Lecture 3: Cultural diffusion in creative industries Entrepreneurs always face the challenge of transforming their good ideas into entrepreneurial practices. This section will exemplify this process using cases in different creative sectors in Hong Kong. It will explore the issue of “cultural diffusion” in the creative economy, a process, in which, creativity is produced and disseminated among the audience. The affecting factors (e.g., identity, creative product, business process and technology) will be looked into.  Readings:  Desai, 2011, 109-130; Wolf, 1999, 45-61  Lecture 4: Innovation processes Innovation is not equal entrepreneurship, but it could be critical to successful entrepreneurship. This section discusses the scope of innovation, which transforms technical ideas and knowledge into new products or services or production processes. It uses examples of opera concert and film industry to demonstrate the process of innovation.  Readings:  Vickery, 1997, 177-179; Davis and Scase, 2000, 1-22; Hetcher, 2011, 70-80  Lecture 5: Entrepreneurship features of creative entrepreneurs  What are the characteristics of creative entrepreneurs? To be successful in creative entrepreneurship, you need to know yourself first. Creative entrepreneurs display the traits different from managers in traditional industrial sectors; they represent the new knowledge workers with creative minds and risk taking spirits. Creative entrepreneurs need to remove the barriers of artistic, economic and marketing considerations. Cases from music industry and film industry will be used to illustrate the issues.  Readings:  Malloy, 2011, 15-18; Glick, 2008, 73-80  Lecture 6: Exploring business opportunities and models for entrepreneurship  Creative products are delivered on two levels: artists and creative entrepreneurs on the one level; and the state and state entrepreneurship on the other level. This section explores how artists and entrepreneurs are fused, and examines business models for entrepreneurship in media and design industries.  Readings:  Bruin, 2007, 87-106;  Harris and Wegg-Prosser, 2009, 229-248  Lecture 7: Guest lecture: The experience from the industries  One or two guest speakers will be invited from the creative industries to share with the students their entrepreneurial experiences. Students are urged to ask questions and observe the qualities and characteristics of these creative entrepreneurs.   Part 3: Supporting Entrepreneurship in Creative Industry Sectors  Lecture 8: Investment and funding for creative enterprises  This section explores the mechanisms and barriers to creative industries investment. It will also discuss the role of the public sector and the opportunities for problem solving. Partnership, commitment, specialism and genericism are the components that constitute the landscape of investment. This section illustrates the policy context and elaborates the value chain of creative industries investment. A set of tips are provided at the end.  Readings:  Powell, 2010, 175-184; Fleming, 2007, 107-126  Lecture 9: The synergies of higher education, enterprise and innovation Universities link creativity to intellectual property and business opportunities. Knowledge spills over from education and R&D programmes at universities and supports creative entrepreneurship in the surrounding community. This section looks at the developing role of universities in the creative industries. It explores various learning and entrepreneurial models for technological innovation and business engagement at universities.  Readings:  Brooks, 1997, 109-129; Stefik and Stefik, 2010, 17-26  Lecture 10: Human language technologies in the creative industries  Two main technologies in the creative industries, i.e., information and communication technology (ICT) and human language technologies (HLT), are introduced. The key knowledge regards how these language technologies foster entrepreneurship in creative industries. Their practical implications to the creative industries in Hong Kong will be discussed. Readings:  UNTAD, 2010; Mitchell, 2016, 4-15  Lecture 11: Incubating entrepreneurship in creative industry clusters Apart from funding investment, legal protection, technological support and university education, creative industry parks serve as incubators for entrepreneurship in the creative industries. An umbrella concept to be discussed in this section is the “creative milieu,” which is often exemplified by “creative industry parks.” Their characteristics and the central management of the parks in supporting entrepreneurship will be examined.  Readings:  CCPR, 2003, 75-184; Mommaas, 2004, 507-532; Maskell, 2000, 1-6; Scott, 1997, 73-80  Fieldtrip: Visiting creative policy makers A fieldtrip will be organized to expose students to the government officials at the Innovation and Technology Bureau. It will help them to understand Hong Kong creative industry policies and the intellectual property law.   Lecture 13: Course summary In the last section, students will deliver their group presentations for feedback and discussion. An overview of the key knowledge in this course will be provided and practical implications will be discussed.

title: Curating and Organising Arts Festival
description: With a global growing interest in organizing grand scale arts and cultural activities to attract local and overseas audience, arts festivals have become popular urban cultural events for cultural development and for building the reputation of a city. Curating and managing cultural festival is subsequently an important area of studies in cultural management. Curating and organizing arts festival is a complex process that requires creative programming, skillful execution and careful financial control. This course not only studies the mode of operations of various types of cultural festivals, including festivals of performing arts, visual arts, film, literary arts and community festive celebration, but also introduces to students the basic skills and knowledge of curating and organizing arts festivals, with references to local and overseas examples.
outcome: - Understand the operation format, management process in organizing various types of cultural festivals; - Have the ability to curate and coordinate programmes within a specific arts/cultural festival; - Learn the supporting skills for successful implementation of arts/cultural festival, including publicity, marketing, public safety, security and finance control; - Equip students with the critical skills to review and evaluate the success and failure of a major cultural event.
syllabus: 1. Cultural Festival: an introduction  This session studies the history, social functions and basic modes of operation of cultural festivals, with examples from Hong Kong and fromvarious parts of the world.  2. Various types of festivals and their distinctive characters  This session introduces various types of arts festival, from festivals focusing on specific media, grand scale multi-disciplinary festivals, to community based religious/celebrative events, with emphasis on studying their own distinctive characteristics and special technical requirements.  3. Planning cultural festival 1:  This session focuses on programme planning and coordination, as well as resource management within the institutional and community context.  4. Planning festival 2:  This session deals with the planning of setting up an operation framework, allocation of manpower, design of the technical support and working out an operational schedule for a major arts festival.  5. Planning festival 3:  Funding is an essential part of organizing cultural festivals. This session studies the various ways to seek public and private fund, and ways to do financial planning and to exercise financial control over the running of projects.  6. Planning festival 4:  In addition to curating and implementing programmes, a successful festival also includes much supporting activities, ranging from marketing to educational events. This session focuses on the studies of these supplementary activities in order to get the best results for an arts event.  7. Presentation and discussion Students are asked to form groups to work on proposals for an arts festival. Students are to do their representations at class, and engage in discussion after the presentations.  8. Curation and programming This session studies the curation of festival programmes with references to local cultural strength and needs, the use of available resources, as well as a study of the global trends in arts festival.  9. Execution and crisis management This session studies the security measure for major cultural events, and preparations required for unexpected incidents and crisis.   10. Case studies Using the Hong Kong Arts Festival and Hong Kong Film Festival for case studies, this session studies the actual implementation of cultural festivals within the specific social, cultural and financial context of Hong Kong.  11. Evaluation and research The success of a festival depends heavily on responses from the audience, the press and the public, this session studies the application of marketing strategies and its consequent results, and ways to make meaningful evaluation for future development.  12. Critical issues relating to arts festival As arts and cultural festivals become increasingly prolific, its social and cultural impacts are not to be underestimated. This session takes on a critical review of the impacts, the pro and con of organizing arts festivals, as well as possible alternatives.  13. Review and discussion This session reviews the entire course and engages students in an over-all discussion.

title: Interpreting Chinese Antiquities
requirements: Not for students who have taken CUMT4101 Special Topics in Cultural Management (Heritage, Archaeology and Interpretation theme)
description: From the perspective of archaeology, this course is tailored to cross disciplinary boundaries between heritage and contemporary issues. The world of ancient China is a rich source of inspirations for museum work; tourism; films and documentary; literature; designs; and even commercial productions. Yet misinterpretations over Chinese history have led to problematic descriptions of heritage and archaeological sites. Indeed, there have not been many discussions of Chinese historical past independent of texts, and this course intends to fill up the lacuna. Taking ancient and medieval China as subjects, this course leads student to appreciate Chinese arts and archaeological finds from between the Neolithic and the 13th century. The course urges students to develop acute senses in reading and writing about heritage for contemporary needs.
outcome: Upon completion of the course, students would be able to identify key historical sites and remains of pre-modern China; analyze the roles and management of heritage or its relevant institutions; think critically about historical exhibitions and other cultural events; develop acute senses for appreciating traditions and values; develop interests in culture and history; and get prepared for career related to management of heritage and arts industries.
syllabus: 1. Introduction: Why is material culture? What is heritage?  What is the difference between history and archaeology? Why should we pay attention to material objects? This session introduces the discipline of archaeology and describes its application in China. It defines what we speak of Chinese heritage from the perspective of material remains.   2. Neolithic China: The Rise of Numerous Jade-using Sources  As of 2014, more than 10 different Neolithic cultures have been identified in China. To what extent have we moved beyond the old understanding about Yangshao and Longshan cultures in central China? What do the new finds tell us about China during the Neolithic times (c.5000—c.2000 BC). And how do they fit into the unified picture of what we call ‘China’ today.   3. The Shang period: the Dawn of Civilization  There are some textual descriptions about the Shang dynasty. But its archaeological boundaries are subject to debates. This session introduces the key Shang sites in Henan, as well as their contemporary sites found in Sichuan, Hunan, and other Chinese provinces. It leads student to pay attention to the interpretation presented in most Chinese museum—all Bronze Age cultures were re-think the connections between the early Bronze Age and the present.   4. Western Zhou: The Early Development of Cultural Borrowings Western Zhou is understood as one of the most esteemed periods in antiquity. This session looks into the archaeological finds from the 10th to 8th century BC and discusses what bronzes tell us about the several important political decisions the Zhou courts made to consolidate sovereignty. One key policy that the Zhou founders implemented was adaptation to various cultural streams collected from the preceding Shang and other neighbouring groups. This was an unknown yet profoundly important aspect of the Zhou that prepared it for taking the lead of what we today call ‘Chinese’ civilization.   5. Eastern Zhou: The Age of Conformity The flourishing workshops of bronze-casting, lacquers, pottery, and textiles from the Eastern Zhou period provide a vast number of important archaeological finds. This session introduces some key sites, which include Sanmengxia and Leigudun. From them we will discuss the significance of material culture in forming shared heritage roots.  Reading: Sullivan 2008, chapter 1, pp. 45—63.  6. Han I: Burial Culture The Han dynasty is a promising period with many textual records and archaeological finds. This first session looks into the Han tomb structure and burial goods, which present some interesting patterns in the religious ideas and practices of the period.  Reading: Sullivan 2008, chapter 1, pp. 65—97.  7. Han II: the Silk Road Connections with the West were well-formed under the Han regime. This session looks at the finds from the Silk Road, which continued to be in use throughout the Han and its following centuries. This session reviews the finds from the Silk Road and discusses their significance for both the intellectual and public sphere in the present times.  Reading: Sullivan 2008, chapter 1, pp. 65—97.  8. Northern & Southern Dynasties: Buddhism in China Buddhism began to appear in China from the Han times, and became vastly important throughout the divided Northern and Southern dynasties. This session introduces the key caves of Buddhist sculpture and discusses the impacts of Buddhist ideas on later Chinese material creations. In particular, Buddhism helped develop a range of ornamental features unprecedentedly formed in the context of China; yet those features have become central in the presentation of Chinese heritage today.  Reading: Sullivan 2008, chapter 1, pp. 99—129  9. Tang Dynasty: The Cosmopolitan Cities  This session focuses on the settlement finds from the Tang period. Little is known about ancient Chinese cities or settlement sites, which were prone to destruction. This session leads students to reflect on the urban life in Metropolitan Tang, which was benefited from the access to various exotic goods acquired through the Silk Road.  Reading: Sullivan 2008, chapter 1, pp. 131—161.  10. Song I: Antiquarianism and Imperial Collections of Arts The Song dynasty was the age of the studies of antiquities. This lecture introduces the early catalogues of imperial collections that developed the sense of shared inheritance from the ninth century.  Reading: Sullivan 2008, chapter 1, pp. 163—205.  11. Song II: Mural Paintings  Mural paintings are important finds from the tombs of the Song period. They usually represent the tomb owners in household quarters, engaged in various activities. More importantly, the neighbouring Qidan and Jin peoples also copied such tradition. This session leads student to discuss the importance in the exchange of burial practices and ideas.  Reading: Sullivan 2008, chapter 1, pp. 163—205.  12. Guest lecture/field trip, venue to be decided.  This session will bring some fresh air to the classroom by taking students to look at modern presentation of Chinese material culture. The permanent gallery of the Hong Kong Art Museum will be a good choice. But it depends on the range of exhibitions available during the teaching period. If possible, a trip to visit the site in Guangzhou or Shenzhen will produce constructive impression about modern understanding of China past.   13. Conclusion and discussions of final papers.  This session summarizes the key issues collected from the above lectures. This is hoped to open up discussions for students to review the various sources of traditions that were gathered to form the core of Chinese civilization.

title: Museum Studies
requirements: Not for students who have taken ANTH4720 or HIST5514
description: Museums have multiple roles in a society. They are academic institutes and public arenas for education. In the broad term, they represent national culture and communal heritage. This course leads students to understand museum exhibitions and management within social contexts. The lectures respond to the following issues:1. What are the functions and achievements of museum activities?2. In what ways can we understand and learn from an exhibition? What are the essential elements of museum catalogues and cultural writing?3. How do museum workers balance both marketing and social needs?4. In what ways can we participate in the operation of a museum?The course draws discussions from both the perspectives of museum workers and visitors. Some current issues concerning the roles of museums are also covered.
outcome: At the end of the course, students should be able to:  1. Identify the roles and management of museums;  2. Develop acute senses for art appreciation;  3. Develop interests in culture and history; and  4. Think critically about museum exhibitions and other cultural events.
syllabus: 1 Introduction:What is a museum?  The introduction gives an overview of the museum structure and definition. This will introduce the various types of museums established around the world, defined according to the range of their collections. This will also compare the organization structure of a museum, in which the curatorial teams are working with a range of specialists relevant.   2 The history of museums  The ‘history’ of museum sounds alien to the context of museum studies. But museum workers are coming to beware that the museums are products of modernity that marked a distinctive times in which antiquities could be treated as shared, public properties. This lecture reviews the establishments of the Louvre and the British Museum in the 18th century; and discusses how ‘museums’ were contextualized first in Japan and later on in China.   3 Curatorship I: Exhibiting Authenticity and Interpretation As the last lecture recalls, ‘Museum as Ritual’ has become an established social understanding—museum is a place where esteemed objects are being exhibited and therefore recognized. The first problem that encounters all museum works is whether the objects they are showing, or the theme of the objects that they are presenting are ‘authentic’. In this lecture, we will look at examples of some early colonial museums and study the created themes that they presented.   4 Curatorship II: Organizing a thematic exhibition Putting up a thematic exhibition (alongside the permanent exhibition) is a common practice in most museums. This lecture will give instructions as to what elements a thematic show should include. Then students are organized into groups to do a role play session for three parties: museum workers, overseas collaborators, and the donors. From this exercise, students will learn about the difficulties in negotiations and planning.   5 Curatorship III: Museum publications and cultural writings The writings published for the museums share a common theme of identifying the artistic or historical values of the objects. In practice, however, there are various levels in addressing objects through literary practices. This lecture will look into some representative examples written for different targeted groups, which include children, pupils, and foreign visitors.   6 Museum and society I: Architecture and Design Renovation projects were undertaken in numerous renowned museums around the world, because it has become aware that museums have to catch up with young generations and with the rapidly developed cities, in which they are located. This lecture will look into the case of Doha Quarter, where the locals took a deliberate attempt to a museum compound. From such we will consider the significance of architecture and museum collection.   7 Museum and society II: Education and Application of Digital Technology  Smartphones and other technological devices have become useful sources for museum presentations and visits. This lecture reviews some applications both within the museum building and outside it. The lecture will also respond to the concerns that digital technologies may exhaust public interests in the museum collections. With these both sides of argument, this lecture leads students to consider both the usefulness and shortcomings of digital technologies.   8 Museum and society III: Patrons, Donors and Volunteers, the sources of Funding and Support Funding is always limited for cultural institutions. In this lecture, we will discuss the various potential fund sources for the museums. There is no standard way in the industry as to what the museum workers should do or write to apply for funding. But there are recognized sources about which they could get in touch: public visitors, membership programmes, volunteers, donars, and governmental resources. The key of the lecture is to develop an open mind to expand the coverage of funding from monetary values to public recognition.   9 Current issue I: Museum Branding and Marketing Museum branding has been identified as a major marketing strategy for cultural institution. In this lecture, we will look at the suggestions of some successful museum workers and study their marketing approaches by creating a brand for museums.   10 Current issue II: Soft Power and the Political Roles of Museums. As soon as Joseph Nye published his idea about soft power, which is based on the dissemination of cultural products or ideas, the discussion is always concerned with museum exhibitions. Museums could be taken as political statement of national treasures. In this lecture, we will discuss the ideas of Nye and look at how such concept has been interpreted in Asia.   11 Fieldtrip/site visit week  This week we will take some fresh air by visiting a local museum/site.   12 Current issue III: Museums and Contemporary Arts.  Should we include contemporary art in the context of museum? This is a difficult question that happens to most museums around the world. The well-used resolution is construction of a new venue dedicated to contemporary arts. The differences between the two disciplines—museums and contemporary arts—are related to the level of curatorship and public recognition. But the two themes seem to have blurred since the last decade.   13 Current issue IV: M+ and other museums in Hong Kong In this last session, we will return our discussion to Hong Kong and look at what options this city has in comparison from what we have seen in other parts of the world. The M+ is dedicated to contemporary arts, or experimental arts; but the local museums remain fairly traditional in terms of collection and their range of exhibitions. Can Hong Kong develop a cultural hub? If so, what roles do these institutes would play?

title: Integrated Studies in Cultural Management
description: This course is continuation of CUMT1001, Introduction to Cultural Management, and looks at cultural management from the macro perspective. Successful culture managers work to maintain healthy balance between culture and its relevant fields of interests, which sometimes could turn harmful or beneficial to the growth and development of the corresponding cultural area. The first session discusses the mutual dependence between culture and various areas, which include laws, economy, community, national interests, and art practitioners. In practice, cultural managers usually have to conform to the values and ethnics of the corresponding countries. For that reason, the second session will look at the approach taken in a few remarkable examples, which Taiwan, China, Singapore, South Korea, U.K., and the U.S.
outcome: Upon completion of the course, students will be able to explain different national and social concerns for preserving culture; to identify the legal and ethnic issues relevant to cultural productions; to identify marketing strategies in cultural promotion; to evaluate the measures for maximizing the input of art practitioners; and to describe the various successful cultural schemes implemented in overseas countries.
syllabus: Section I: Culture in Context   1. Culture & States The growth of cultural industries is strongly related to political environment and state policy. This lecture discusses the tension and mutual expectations between cultural workers and politicians. It will use the experience of the European Union and the US as examples.   2. Culture & Laws Over the last few decades, there were a number of remarkable disputes over international art transactions and copy rights. Given the growing size of the art market, knowledge about the previous cases is essential. This lecture takes the examples taken from the US for discussions.   3. Culture & UNESCO UNESCO is arguably a rising new power in forming a standard for evaluating cultural heritage of different nations. This lecture discusses the roles of UNESCO and its work in different cultural disciplines. National disputes over ownership of World Heritage sites will be bought up.   4. Culture & Community Nowadays many nations and countries perceive culture and heritage as means to empower developing communities. This lecture discusses the conservation of indigenous or minorities cultures, and its impacts on the majority population of the same community.   5. Culture & Marketing  Culture and business are often taken as two contrasting disciplines. One of the key issues in cultural management is to develop cultural audience with both education and economic concerns. Religious sectors are a growing body of cultural venues for tourism and heritage management. This lecture discusses the debated concerns about conducting marketing or business-driven strategies in cultural and religious areas.   Section II: Case Studies 6. Cultural Management in Taiwan Taiwan provides an excellent example to demonstrate the top-down organization of heritage sites. This lecture reviews a series of campaigns launched in Taiwan during the past twenty years, and discusses the reasons that may have contributed to engage the mass of Taiwan into different aspects of cultural industries.   7. Cultural Management in China China represents many upcoming opportunities in cultural management. This lecture reviews some recent moves: rapid establishment of museums, growing number of commercial galleries and auction houses, rise of new Confucian schools, introduction of university degrees in cultural management, etc. The lecture discusses the consuming force underneath the cultural growth in the Mainland.   8. Cultural Management in Singapore During the last two decades, the government of Singapore invested heavily on constructing cultural venues for both national and economic purposes. This lecture gives an overview of their establishment and invites students to reflect on the opportunities found in other areas of Asia.   9. Cultural Management in South Korea This lecture discusses the contemporary cultural policies undertaken in South Korea. During the last decade, South Korea featured an economic miracle in Asia by rejuvenating the distressed financial market with cultural developments, which included the film industry, heritage protection, publication, and cultural tourism.   10. Cultural Management in UK The United Kingdom was one of the earliest countries that invested heavily on promotion of cultural and arts events. This lecture gives a short history of the early developments made in the UK after the Second World War, and discusses the recent campaigns undertaken to break the boundaries between high arts and popular culture.   11. Cultural Management in USA The United States distinguishes herself from all other countries by boosting the absence of a ministry for arts and culture, yet artists and cultural workers receive due respects for their contributions. This lecture looks at the case of the US and examines her success in cultural management.   12. Group presentation This lecture is taken as a mock symposium for students to present their group projects and make comments on those by their peers. The presentation will be evaluated against the clarity and thoughts over the approved topics.   13. Conclusion: What is the best for Hong Kong?  This last session will summarize the topics covered throughout the course. Hong Kong is facing the challenge that many aspects of cultural developments in relation to urban planning, legislation, economy, national identity, and education are all pending. This lecture is an open discussion for students to brainstorm the possible approaches that Hong Kong could take in years to come.

title: Culture-led City Development
description: This course aims to provide students with a comprehensive understanding of the culture-led city development phenomenon and equip them with the protocols for execution and practice. It comprises three blocks: Block 1 unfolds an overall picture of the phenomenon, introduces the related concepts, displays the disciplinary foundation of this topic, traces its history, and discusses the rationales and developing tendency. Block 2 studies the urban sociological and economic approaches employed in developing the theoretical foundation, highlighting a transition in capitalist production mode and urban governance upheld by public-private partnership modes. Criticisms are also presented to complete a dialectic mindset of this phenomenon. With a strong practical dimension, Block 3 teaches students various methods to make consultancy and policy recommendations for culture-led urban development projects. A variety of practices that constitute the culture-led strategy are discussed, such as how to plan for a creative city and cultural facilities, how to boost creative industries and develop cultural quarters and creative clusters, as well as how to revitalize historic quarters.
outcome: Students are introduced to the basic concept of the culture-led urban development phenomenon, recognizing related concepts, understanding its history, and developing tendencies in the world. Then, they can gain a deep theoretical understanding of the origins of these practices in a capitalist political economic transition, the corresponding urban policies, and the urban governance modes. Moreover, students can learn how to conduct policy analysis and apply urban planning and design principles to provide consultancy for culture-led city development projects. The final products of group projects shall consist of policy recommendations and project consultancies for the Hong Kong government or other private sector developers.
syllabus: Part 1: Introduction to the Culture-led City Development Phenomenon 1. Culture-led City Development: A Topic of Popularity With a glimpse into a number of cities in Europe, America, and Asia that have implemented culture-led urban regeneration strategies, this lecture aims to spark the students’ initial interest in this global phenomenon. This lecture identifies the disciplinary foundations of the topic—from cultural studies, economic geography, and urban sociology to urban planning and design. Furthermore, this lecture examines the concept of culture in the culture-led city development phenomenon, emphasizing the increasing importance of culture in the related disciplines in the mindset of “culture determining.” The role of culture in generating profits, jobs, and other economic returns, being interwoven with local governance and identity is discussed.   2. Concepts, History, Rationale, and Debate This section introduces a set of concepts closely related to that of “culture-led city development,” such as “cities of culture,” “property-led development” and “culture-led regeneration,” and differentiates the nuances among these concepts. The theories that argue for the role of culture in city formation and urban development are discussed, in which culture is viewed as resource or capital leading to symbolic economy that valorizes cities. A related issue is the role of cultural planning, which offers the resources and the framework in the process. The other theoretical source under scrutiny in this section is the importance of city or an urban environment to the growth of culture and cultural consumption. The writings of Jane Jacobs, Sharon Zukin, and Grame Evans are introduced.  Tutorial: Discuss selected readings.    Part 2: Urban Sociological and Economic Approach to Understanding Culture-led Urban Regeneration 3. Politics, Cultural Policies, and Culture-led City Development Strategies  This section explores the theoretical foundation of the culture-led city development phenomenon within the context of political economy. The transition of the capitalist production mode from Fordist economy to market-led post-Fordist economy has led to corresponding transitions in urban policies and urban governance modes, as well as to the adoption of public-private partnership. Culture-led city development strategy is a strategy, which is in line with the entrepreneurial urban policies. In addition, this section examines the connection between the culture-led city development strategies and the transformed cultural policies in cities. The broadening of the policy focus from art amenity provision to cultural economy development and urban cultural spaces planning has been identified as the most important policy context. Three stages of culture-led urban regeneration in terms of policies are also explained in detail.  Tutorial: Discuss selected readings.  4. Economy of Culture and Arts in Cities  This section discusses the economic importance of culture and arts in cities. Culture is viewed as a new driver in urban economic growth, and the cultural sector is viewed as an indicator of urban economic growth. The economic importance of culture is associated with the so-called “symbolic economy” in cities, which involves upgrading urban images and boosting cultural consumption (e.g., urban tourism) within specific urban economies. Cultural and creative industries are the other main focal points of this lecture; thus, the geographic dimensions of cultural and creative industries are explored in this section. Furthermore, this lecture elaborates on the characteristics of cultural industry businesses and organizations, the geographic distribution of networks, and their production and consumption modes. Finally, a method to measure cultural and creative industries in cities is introduced.  Tutorial: Discuss selected readings.   5. Culture-led Urban Regeneration Regimes and Cultural Strategies Bianchini divides cultural culture-led city development strategies into culture-production-led and culture-consumption-led regeneration approaches. This section explores four types of production-led regeneration regimes and the consumption-led regime mode; cultural strategies and their interactions with modes of cultural production are also discussed. In addition, this section addresses the question of whether cultural strategies affect the conditions of cultural production. Finally, a method to fund cultural strategies is studied. Tutorial: Discuss selected readings.   6. Urban Governance and Partnership Modes in Culture-led City Development  What are the urban governance modes that match individual culture-led city development practices? The transformation of urban governance and partnership modes, which is a response to the change in the capitalist production mode, is an important issue in understanding of culture-led urban development practices. Partnership is not simply a transition from managerial to entrepreneurial form but a public sector-led management to local public-private partnership to manage their opportunities effectively in the global economic background. This section explores the characteristics of urban governance and public-private partnership. This knowledge can be applied in creating cultural quarters, CCJQs, and cultural facilities in Block 3.  Tutorial: Discuss selected readings.  7. Critiques on Culture-led Urban Regeneration Culture-led urban development strategies result in positive urban outcomes; however, they can also have negative impacts. This section presents the criticisms against culture-led urban development. For example, designation and zoning of cultural quarters often lead to the gentrification effect that cuts off poor artists from industrial studios. Flagship cultural facilities have a high chance of failure, often resulting in social exclusion and economic inequality and trigger tensions between cultural diversity and cultural hegemony. Moreover, the contribution of cultural projects to employment and GDP is questioned. Tutorial: Discuss selected readings.    Part 3: Strategies and Mechanisms for Practice: Policies, Urban Planning, and Design Tools 8. Cultural Planning and Creative Cities  This section introduces the concept of “cultural planning” as well as its goals, principles, and rationale for practice. The major steps for practice are discussed briefly. The second issue in this lecture is related to creative city and creative milieu. Based on the concept of “creative city” introduced in CUMT1001, this lecture discusses the principles and methods to create a creative milieu for a city. Further discussions are based on the insights of Landry regarding the components of creative cities and Hall about the characteristics and preconditions for the creation of creative cities.  Mid-term Test  9. Boosting Cultural and Creative Industries in Cities  This section discusses a method of using policy and planning tools to boost cultural and creative industries in cosmopolitan cities. First, the three stages of cultural industry development in connection with cultural policy transformations in history are reviewed. Second, a method is introduced, by which policies for cultural and creative industry development can be designed and initiated. Sophisticated analyses of local resources of arts, cultural industries and their interconnections, along with production chain linkage and planning assessment, comprise the key steps in creating effective policy designs. The geographic convergence of cultural businesses and creative industry undertakings in the form of clustering has been argued to be a possible mechanism to facilitate the growth of cultural and creative industries. Finally, the principles and methods to generate CCJQs using policy and planning methods are outlined in this section. Tutorial: Draft a proposal aimed at transforming Hong Kong into a creative city.  10. Planning for Public Arts, Arts Amenities, and Cultural Facilities Developing cultural facilities through urban planning and design is an integral part of culture-led urban development. This section examines the position of arts amenities in urban policies through various historical stages, as well as the transition from emphasizing arts amenity provision to cultural facilities in urban planning. The main content of this lecture is devoted to providing instruction with regard to the ways by which to plan for cultural facilities in cosmopolitan cities, with an outline of the main approaches, such as providing cultural facilities as per the related planning codes with complementary methods of survey, designing a hierarchical system of cultural facility provision, developing facilities of mixed-use, and engaging member of the community. The anti-planning approach to creating cultural spaces is also included, the core concern of which involves a flexibly use of public and community spaces and family-centered virtual media facilities.  Tutorial: Analyze the policies of Hong Kong’s cultural and creative industries, and draft policy recommendations for creative industry development in Hong Kong.  11. Creating Cultural Quarters  Cultural quarters, rooted in post-Fordist economy, have become an integral part of urban regeneration regime, which represents a transition in urban cultural policies toward a more comprehensive stage. This section discusses the political and economic importance of cultural quarters, the rationale of clustering cultural activities and creative industry businesses, and the typology of cultural quarters. Students are also introduced to the strategies and principles for creating cultural quarters based on Roodhouse’s writings in 2006. Urban design skills to enhance the robustness of buildings and create vibrant street spaces and pedestrian spaces are complemented to Roodhouse’s principles. Possible solutions to control gentrification are also discussed using the case of Lace Market. The final part of this section presents the instructor’s consultancy project for the West Kowloon Cultural District. Tutorial: Come up with recommendations for improving cultural facilities in Hong Kong.  12. Heritage Conservation and Historic Urban Quarter Revitalization The significance of historical buildings and urban heritage sites in making a creative urban creative milieu and the process of disseminating symbols through cultural consumption-led urban spaces have been covered by previous sections. In this section, students are introduced to the historical transition and developing tendency of historic buildings and heritage conservation from preserving individual buildings to area-based conservation. With a clarification of the meaning of historic quarters, this section focuses on the selection of appropriate approaches or strategies that can be used in revitalizing historic urban quarters. These methods include preservation and conservation controls as well as physical and economic revitalization based on the assessment of the type of obsoletion.  Tutorial: Consultancy report for a cultural district in Hong Kong  13. The Workshop: Making Culturally Reenergized Cities In this section, the final group is expected to present their group project on historical quarter revitalization in Hong Kong. To wrap up this course, the final section summarizes all the key issues and points. Supplemental instructions are provided based on the progress of the students’ group projects, after which all comments on each group’s projects are synthesized. One or two mechanisms might be introduced to strengthen the students’ capacity to apply the theories learned, such as the evaluation matrix for cultural quarters and historic building reuses. A Q&A section is then included to answer students’ questions concerning the knowledge in this course. Moreover, additional supervision for individual group projects is provided as needed.
